dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long shadows as the sun goes down. A field, by a road, lined with a fence. Snagged in the barbed wire are hundreds of plastic bags. Refuse and litter, blown by the wind, until they were caught.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m twenty six years old, and I’ve been a carer now for seven years. By the road, a car is parked up against the grass verge. Standing by the car, a young woman with blonde hair, KATH looks towards the fields.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My donors have always tended to do better than expected. They are hardly ever classified as agitated, even before a fourth donation. cuT To -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the same woman, KATHY, standing at the window of an observation room. She is absentmindedly twisting a metal bracelet on her wrist, which is featureless except for an imprinted seven digit number. Through the glass, she is watching NURSES and SURGEONS prepping a twenty six year-old man for operation. TOMMY.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p2.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to boast. It means a lot to me, being able to do my work well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOMMY is in the process of being sedated. He also wears a metal bracelet. Beside him, an ANESTHETIST is inserting a drip into his arm.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Especially keeping the donors calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOMMY turns his head to look at KATHY. Their locked gaze is held for a beat. Then KATHY nods. Very slight. As if to say: it’s okay. TOMMY continues looking a moment longer. Then the ANESTHETIST’S drug takes a hold of him. seconds, his eyes have gone heavy, then closed.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I’m not making any great claims for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a few The plastic bags in the barbed wire snap and rustle in th wind.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I understand how other carers can be resentful. They say: she’s from Hailsham. No wonder she has a great record. She can pick and choose her own kind. As we CLOSE IN on KATHY, leaning against the car, her hai caught and whipped in the same wind... «+. FADE IN the sound of children playing.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p3.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And it’s true. Hailsham was special. We were lucky. Tommy, Ruth, me. All of us. cuT To -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAILSHAM SCHOOL: a large Victorian house, set in flat, empty countryside. The sky above is bright blue and cloudless. The sun is bright. It is an idyll of early summer. The extensive grounds of the school are surrounded by hig hedgerows. Nothing seems to connect it with the rest of the world except a single grey ribbon of road. Title:

dialogues.speaker: NEVER LET ME GO
dialogues.text: The title is not seen, but is SPOKEN by TOMMY. After a few seconds, a title does appear on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In sunlight, two girls, aged twelve, lie on their bellies on a patch in front of the main house. Both wear the metal bracelets - as do all students at Hailsham, and all other facilities like it. The grass is strewn with daisies. One girl has blonde hair. This is KATHY. The other is dark. This is RUTH. KATHY is interlocking the stems of the small flowers, frowning in concentration, making a daisy chain.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I think one day I'd like...  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p4. RUTH pauses. Thinking a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Four horses. (beat) No, five. Thunder, Bramble, Daffodil, and... RUTH trails off.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know all their names. But I'd like five horses. (beat) The best would be Thunder. He'd be dangerous to ride, so you can’t ride him. You can ride Bramble. (beat) As long as you don’t use your crop on him.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t anyway. I would have thought that’s mean. KATHY makes the last link. She lifts the daisy chain delicately.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Pretty.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: You have it. KATHY places it over RUTH’S blonde hair... «+. where it looks like it belongs.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: «+. Look. KATHY follows RUTH’S gaze. By the entrance of the main house, two women have appeare One is older, in her mid sixties. This is MISS EMILY, the head guardian of Hailsham. The other is younger, in her late twenties.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who's that with Miss Emily? Do you think it’s the new guardian they were telling us about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p5.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Miss Lucy. I think it must be.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: We haven’t had a new guardian for ages. A moment, as the two girls watch the two women, squinting against the bright sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wonder if she’ll fit in. cuT To -

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HAILSHAM DAY
dialogues.text: A group of boys in their PE kits, run through an outdoor covered walkway, watched by a CCTV camera -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - then onto the playing fields, watched by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. a group of girls, watching from the shade of a large ornate gate near the main building. The girls are joined by KATHY and RUTH.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ruth. Kath. Look - they’re going to set off Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Light blue touch paper and stand well back!

dialogues.speaker: 8A
dialogues.text: 10 On the playing field, we see the boy they are referring t TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He really doesn’t suspect a thing. The girls all laugh - - except KATHY. KATHY watches TOMMY with slight concern.  11 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pé6.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: He’s got his shirt on... His favourite polo shirt. From their vantage point, the girls can now see the boys have started lining up. Two CAPTAINS have stepped forward and are about to start picking teams. One of the two captains is ARTHUR, a sporty boy who feels as Alpha male as Tommy feels Delta. The CAPTAINS start choosing team members. TOMMY stands - almost a comical figure, puffing out his chest in order t make himself stand out. The other boys are noticeably less keen. Chatting, or checking the tightness of their boot laces. Even from a distance, we can sense TOMMY’S shift from bright eagerness to puzzled concern, as four boys are chosen before him... Then five... six...

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It’s coming. Hold on... any moment now... «+. Until eventually TOMMY is left standing alone. Realising he hasn’t been picked. And isn’t going to be picked. The boys all start sniggering.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seven seconds. Six, five, four, three... And SUDDENLY - before RUTH’S countdown can complete - TOM explodes. Head is thrown back. Bright red. Shaking. Screaming. The BOYS are now laughing openly - - then start to run away, on to the football pitch. Leaving TOMMY alone, directing his rage at the clear blue sky, arms and legs oddly rigid.

dialogues.speaker: DELETED
dialogues.text: 12 13 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls watch, a mixture of transfixed and absently amused by this strange sight.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I suppose it is a bit cruel, the way they work him up like that. But it’s his own fault. If he learned to keep his cool, they'd leave him alone. RUTH looks to KATHY, as if for approval - - but doesn’t get it. KATHY has stood, and is walking away from the gate toward TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY approaches TOMMY, who is panting from the exertion his tantrum, still gazing up at the sky. KATHY puts a hand on TOMMY’S arm - - and TOMMY recoils violently, throwing his arm up, knocking her hand aside and striking the side of her face The strike is an accident - a reaction of surprise and confusion more than anger - but TOMMY seems even more shocked than KATHY by what he has done. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Isn't that your favourite shirt? TOMMY says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just wanted to say, you shouldn't play football in that shirt. You’1l only cover it in mud.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (mumbling, a little stunned) So what? It’s nothing to do with you anyway. TOMMY starts to walk away. KATHY watches him go.  14 15 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY rejoins the girls, who are coming out of the pavilion, and make an outraged fuss over her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Kath?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I can’t believe he hit you!

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I don’t think he meant to.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Are you bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He’s an animal. That’s what I think. KATHY doesn’t respond, and instead looks back to the playing field. Where she sees TOMMY - - standing on the edge of the playing field, talking to t new guardian, MISS LUCY. TOMMY and MISS LUCY are too distant for us to hear their conversation, but we can read some of the body language, when MISS LUCY reaches out and touches him lightly on the shoulder. * Whatever MISS LUCY is saying, TOMMY is listening intently

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A mad animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children are lined to enter the MATRON’S office for a medical examination. The children are neatly lined, but chatting, and unconcerned. These examinations are completely routine. At the head of the queue are KATHY, RUTH and AMANDA. A group of three children exit MATRON’S office, followed MATRON herself.  16 17 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH po.

dialogues.speaker: MATRON
dialogues.text: Next. INT. MATRON’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS 16 KATHY, RUTH and AMANDA are being examined by the MATRON, and two male DOCTORS. The presence of the two DOCTORS, and some high-tech piece of medical equipment, feel unnatural. One of the DOCTORS is listening to RUTH’S chest with a stethoscope. AMANDA stands in front of the second DOCTOR, with her arm raised. The man is using his hands to feel around her bar torso, as if looking for lump tumours or sensitivities. MATRON is examining KATHY, making notes on a clipboard headed: KATHY H She tilts KATHY’S head to the side, frowning slightly at the slight bruise from where TOMMY accidentally struck he

dialogues.speaker: MATRON
dialogues.text: What’s this from?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: MATRON
dialogues.text: Doctor. The first DOCTOR glances round from RUTH. He peers at KATHY’S bruise critically. For a beat or two longer than would seem appropriate for such a small contusion.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It’s nothing. Just a bump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of the Hailsham students are in the ART ROOM, quietly working on paintings and sculptures. In the corner of the room, another of their guardians, MI GERALDINE, is helping two of the children mix paint colours. At her table, KATHY works on a sculpture.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH plo. Meanwhile, RUTH pointedly leans over to the table beside them, where TOMMY is working.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Tommy. What are you doing? Show us so we can have a look.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (quiet, to Ruth) No, Ruth. Don’t. TOMMY looks up from his drawing, and sees a semi-circle o faces looking back at him. A beat, as he returns their gaze. Then he spins the picture round so that it faces them.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh! It’s a - (she feigns uncertainty) - what is it exactly?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I think it must be a dog. Is it a dog, Tommy? One of the boys, ARTHUR - who had been one of the team- pickers from the playing fields - joins in.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It can’t be a dog. Its eyes are too small. I think it must be a kind of rat.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yes! That’s it! Tommy’s drawn a rat. Ruth, do you think Tommy’s rat will be selected for the gallery?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Why don’t we ask Miss Geraldine to come over and tell us what she thinks? CLOSE UP on TOMMY’S face - flushing.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It’s not finished yet.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: That’s right. You need to draw the whiskers.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It’s not a rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pll.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: And a longer tail.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (voice rising) It's not a rat! On the other side of the room, the raised voice makes MIS GERALDINE’S head turn.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (whispers) Here it comes! The kids goading TOMMY wait expectantly. Then TOMMY speaks. And the calmness has returned to his voice.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It’s not a rat. (beat) It’s an elephant. He spins the picture back to face him, and continues to work on it. RUTH and AMANDA exchange a slightly puzzled glance - - but let it go, because MISS GERALDINE is now walking ov to their table... .+. and the kids return to their respective works. INT. MISS LUCY’S STUDY - DAY 17A In her small study, MISS LUCY is writing at her desk. KATHY appears in the doorway. MISS LUCY seems unaware.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Miss Lucy. MISS LUCY looks up. Then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MISS LUCY
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Kathy. Kathy H.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pl2.

dialogues.speaker: MISS LUCY
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Kathy H. Come in. KATHY takes a step into MISS LUCY’S office. MISS LUCY (CONT’D) What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I was wondering what you said to Tommy. MISS LUCY doesn’t seem to follow. Perhaps having to remember exactly who TOMMY is.

dialogues.speaker: MISS LUCY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: You said something to Tommy. Out on the playing fields. And whatever it was, it’s had quite an effect on him.

dialogues.speaker: MISS LUCY
dialogues.text: I see. Bemused, but seeing the seriousness in KATHY’S face, MISS LUCY makes an effort to be precise. MISS LUCY (CONT’D) So - what was it I said? I believe I was trying to calm him down, because he seemed so upset. And he explained that he was often teased about things like sport, and art. So I told him that he shouldn’t get upset at these things. The other children are only teasing him to get a reaction. (beat) And if it happens that he isn’t particularly good at sport or art, well - it doesn’t matter. It’s not so important. KATHY frowns.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Not so important. MISS LUCY shrugs, almost as if to shrug off the intense gaze of the little girl in front of her.  18 19 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p13.

dialogues.speaker: MISS LUCY
dialogues.text: No. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch, in Hailsham’s refectory. Trays contain compartments filled with extremely overcook food. Grey meat and faded vegetables. The kids take the trays from the food trolleys, then take seats at long refectory tables. KATHY is carrying her tray with RUTH, AMANDA and LAURA. She sees TOMMY. As the other girls move forwards with their trays... ... KATHY hangs back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOMMY sits at a table with a few spaces around him. We can sense he is used to eating alone. Not least from the surprise in his face when he looks up, and sees KATHY taking the seat opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Kathy. (awkward) Aren’t you sitting with the girls? KATHY looks around, as if half expecting to find the girl either side of her. Then she looks back at TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I just checked, and I’m pretty sure I’m not sitting with the girls. I’m sitting with you. TOMMY smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I wanted to say I was sorry. I didn’t mean to hit you when - (he breaks off) I mean, I wouldn’t want to hit any girl. But particularly not you.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pl4.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Well. It was an accident, that’s all. * A passing guardian, MISS GERALDINE, glances at TOMMY’S * plate. At the collection of over-boiled carrots, not eaten as ye

dialogues.speaker: MISS GERALDINE
dialogues.text: Tommy. Finish those vegetables. MISS GERALDINE moves on. * KATHY leaves a calculated pause.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: So... you didn’t lose your temper when they were teasing you earlier. In the art room. TOMMY nods seriously.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I’m not going to get angry like that any more.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Because of what Miss Lucy told you.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: You notice everything, don’t you, Kath?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I’m nosy.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (smiles) You are. AT THIS MOMENT, the seats immediately beside TOMMY and KATHY are taken by some kids coming over with their trays About to reply, TOMMY seems to think the better of it - apparently uncomfortable about their conversation being overheard.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t we talk about it at the pond.  20 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the back of Hailsham, tucked away in the grounds, is a large pond surrounded by bulrushes and over-hanging trees Hailsham is reflected in the water. It’s quiet. Feels private. TOMMY sits on a large flat rock, with KATHY beside him. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: She can’t actually mean that being creative isn’t important, can she?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: That’s exactly what she meant. She said some children are good at things, and some aren’t. So if I wasn’t creative, there was nothing wrong with it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: But what about the gallery? If being creative isn’t important, then why have a gallery at all?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. (beat) The funny thing is, even though I don’t understand what she’s saying, it helps. I’ve stopped feeling so angry about things, because - (shrugs ) - whatever I’m doing wrong, or doing worse than the rest of you, it isn’t my fault.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think this shouldn't be spread, okay? It’s not the kind of thing that should get around, because Miss Lucy is a new guardian.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. From the litter and detritus are collected at the edge of the pond, CUT TO -  21 22 23 24 25 26 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pl6é.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - a scene from an anonymous film. Black and white, from the thirties, forties or fifties. The scene is a caperish moment of chase, or slapstick... +. which is being watched, with delight, by KATHY, TOMMY, RUTH, ARTHUR, LAURA, and all other students in their year As the moment of slapstick resolves, the kids all shout:

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS
dialogues.text: Again, again! The scene is rewound, and begins again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow MISS GERALDINE down a corridor. MISS GERALDINE is carrying a large stack of papers - drawings and paintings by the students from the artroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS GERALDINE carries the artworks into the billiard roo where we glimpse MISS EMILY and two other GUARDIANS. One of the GUARDIANS closes the door behind MISS GERALDINE... .-. on KATHY and RUTH, who are in the corridor outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now follow KATHY and RUTH, as they run through the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they run out the back door, they hold out their wrists to swipe their metal bracelets against a featureless meta box, attached to the wall. The metal box gives an electronic bleep in acknowledgment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and RUTH continue running, heading around the side the building...  27 28 29 30 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pl7. +. then up onto a low flower-bed wall, which allows them to peer through the window of the billiard room. Where they can see MISS EMILY, MISS GERALDINE, and two others GUARDIANS. They are laying out paintings, drawing and sculptures on tables and easels. Through the glass, we can faintly hear MISS EMILY.

dialogues.speaker: MISS EMILY
dialogues.text: Put these two together. Yes... perfect. I think she’ll find this one very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (quiet, to Kathy) Madame is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A constellation in the night sky above Hailsham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GIRLS’ BATHROOM - NIGHT 28 DELETED. INT. OUTSIDE GIRLS’ DORMITORY - CONTINUOUS 29 DELETED. INT. GIRLS’ DORMITORY - NIGHT 30 Rows of beds in the girls’ dormitory. Beside each bed, a beside table. And on each bedside table, a COLLECTION. KATHY’S collection mainly consists of books, and RUTH’S collection is model horses. KATHY is lying in her bed, looking at the ceiling. Thinking. After a couple of moments, she looks to her side. In the next bed is RUTH, whose eyes are closed.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Ruth.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pls. No response.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ruth. Are you awake?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No. I’m asleep. And this is the dream I’m having.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Why do you think Madame comes and takes our artwork? What’s it for exactly? RUTH’S eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It’s for the Gallery.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: But that’s what I mean. She comes here - what, twice a year - and selects our best pictures and sculptures and poems. And takes them away. (beat) She must have stacks of art by now. I asked Miss Geraldine once how long Madame’s been coming here, and she said for as long as Hailsham’s existed. KATHY rolls over, to face RUTH.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what is this Gallery? And why would she have a gallery of things done by us?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Maybe she sells them. Outside, out there, they sell everything.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Maybe. A moment of silence, as both KATHY and RUTH contemplate these thoughts. Then:

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: She’s scared of us. KATHY frowns, and props herself up in bed.  31

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Madame?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: That's a strange thing to say. RUTH shrugs. Beat. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I used to think she was just snooty, but now I know different.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. How could Madame be scared of us? What could we do to her?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t think we could do anything. But I’ve been remembering her last visit.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Little things. The way she looks at us.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's scared all right.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I bet I could prove it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: «+. How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch as, from a distance, a lone car approaches pl9. Hailsham, along a ribbon of road through the surrounding fields. 31  32 33 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY, RUTH, AMANDA, LAURA, and the five other girls stan in the shadows of Hailsham’s front doorway, watching the CAR approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up on the gravel courtyard of Hailsham, and parks. The driver, MADAME, exits the car, then goes around to th boot - - which she opens. Inside is her luggage - a small overnight bag. She takes it out, closes the boot, then turns - - and STARTS. Because surrounding her, in a tight circle, are the nine girls. There are standing several feet away, not moving. Just looking at MADAME. A beat. Frozen and uncertain for MADAME. Then she starts to walk. And almost as soon as she does so - - the children start to walk too. Moving straight for her. Making her stop again in her tracks, and hold the overnight bag to her chest. In a slightly stiff, glazed way, the girls each murmur, dream-like -

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Excuse me, miss. - as they pass her. Then they separate, each walking in different directions. «+. leaving MADAME alone. It’s a very odd moment. Surreal. But it reveals exactly what RUTH said it would.  34 35 36 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p2l. MADAME’S reaction was as if she was suppressing a shudder A kind of dread in her eyes, looking at the children as i they were spiders. As she was afraid they might reach out and touch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the side of the building, the girls reconvene. One of the girls, LAURA, looks particularly shaken and close to tears.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You saw it, didn’t you? In her face. You all saw it.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: There’s no doubt. Kathy.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (confirms ) No doubt.
