dialogues.text: I didn’t understand why, after all her teasing, Ruth would decide that Tommy was the boy she liked most of all. KATHY watches as RUTH turns TOMMY’S face towards hers.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They say girls are always mean to the boys they like. So maybe Ruth had liked him all along. KATHY stops, as — - RUTH leans forwards to kiss TOMMY. Back to KATHY’S face, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe I should have teased him too. INT. GIRLS’ DORMITORY - DAY 59 KATHY’S collection sits on her bedside table. The small row of books. A fountain pen. And the JUDY BRIDGEWATER cassette. She puts another book into her collection. INT. GIRLS’ DORMITORY - DAY 59A The collection grows. Reveal KATHY, now in her late teens, packing a bag.  60 61 62 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The view across the pond. The school building is reflected in the water. Then splintered into ripples. On this splintered image - FADE TO BLACK. Title:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minibus drives through flat countryside. The bus is being driven by a man in his early sixties - KEFFERS. In the back are six Hailsham students, now aged eighteen. Among them, KATHY, RUTH and TOMMY. KATHY and TOMMY we have seen before in adult incarnation, at the start of the film. RUTH we recognise by the colour of her hair... .+. and by the way her hand is enmeshed in TOMMY’S. All are glazed by the length of the journey. Gazing out of the window, watching the largely featureles landscape slide by.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We left Hailsham at eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The minibus drives up a long dirt road.  63 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p44.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My year were scattered to different locations, but Tommy, Ruth and I were relocated together, to a collection of buildings that had once been a working farm. At the far end of the dirt road, a cluster of farm buildings can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We called them the Cottages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small collection of farm buildings, with a central hous are nestled in remote countryside. But it is not picturesque. It is desolate. Old farm machinery lies where it was last used. A couple of chickens run through the muddy space between the building

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At the time, we thought the Cottages were just a staging post before the donation centers. A MINIBUS pulls up outside, and the students get out, eac carrying a rucksack and a suitcase. They all look slightly taken aback by what they see. KEFFERS directs them unceremoniously to the main house.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But looking back, I can see they were actually a training ground of sorts. During our time there, some of us would be expected to volunteer as carers. As the students walk to the house, they have to pick thei way across the mud. Their shoes are unsuitable. Their clothing looks insufficient for the cold. Standing in the doorway of the main house is a girl. Slightly older. She wears a heavy jumper and Wellington boots. This is CHRISSIE. CHRISSIE watches them blankly as they approach.  64 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p45.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Cottages were also our first contact with those who had not had the privilege of growing up in Hailsham. FADE IN the sound of a TV sitcom LAUGHTER TRACK. cuT To -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the living room are RUTH and TOMMY. They are sitting o a sofa. Ruth is leaning back into TOMMY’S arms. At the other end of the sofa is KATHY. On another sofa is CHRISSIE. Entering the room is RODNEY, CHRISSIE’S boyfriend. As he walks behind CHRISSIE, he gives her shoulder a litt squeeze. Then sits beside her, and she slips her arm into his. As a gesture, it is clingy. As a rule, whenever RODNEY and CHRISSIE are near each other, they hold each other in such a way. All of them have slightly glazed expressions - - because they are watching the TV, which is showing a generic American sitcom, circa early nineties. In the background, other inhabitants of the Cottages come and go. On the floor are empty plates of food, presumably from a dinner eaten in front of the television. CLOSE UP on the TV screen - - where a group of attractive young Americans are sitting around in a New York apartment. One of the HANDSOME BOYS shakes his head at one of the PRETTY GIRLS.

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME BOY
dialogues.text: Hey Jen, what’s this I keep hearing about you and Ricky?

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY GIRL
dialogues.text: Ricky? I don’t know what you’re talking about.  65 66 67 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p46.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh - can help you out there. He’s talking about blue eyes, blonde hair, cute dimples when he smiles, and biceps that can crack walnuts. HANDSOME boy winces.

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME BOY
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh that Ricky.

dialogues.speaker: HANDSOME BOY
dialogues.text: Jennifer, get real. I saw you with him.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY GIRL
dialogues.text: Jen and Ricky, sitting in a tree, K-I-S-S-I-N-G. PRETTY GIRL #1 looks indignant, and rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY GIRL
dialogues.text: That is so not true! (beat) We weren’t in a tree. The laughter track kicks in again. INT. TOMMY’S ROOM - NIGHT 65 RUTH and TOMMY are having sex. RUTH is being slightly noisy, and the movement of the bed is bumping against the wall. INT. KATHY’S ROOM - NIGHT 66 Next door, KATHY lies awake, reading, hearing them. We see that on her bedside table, she has rearranged her collection from Hailsham - including the Judy Bridgewater tape. To block out the noise of RUTH and TOMMY, KATHY puts walkman headphones over her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daybreak over the fields around the Cottages.  68 69 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEFFERS pulls up in his minibus outside the main house. He gets out, and picks up a box of groceries from the passenger seat. As he carries the box across the muddy yard to the main house, he slips. KEFFERS breaks his fall by landing on one knee, and he manages to keep the box of groceries upright. But when he rises, his leg is caked with mud. He looks immensely pissed off. KATHY is standing in the doorway of the main house to tak the box.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Keffers. KEFFERS hands her the box and starts walking back across the yard without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same group of people that were watching TV - KATHY, RUTH, TOMMY, RODNEY and CHRISSIE - are in the kitchen fixing breakfast. CHRISSIE and RUTH are cooking up some scrambled eggs, and the others are sitting at the table. Also at the table are two other young people. One reads a book, and the other eats cereal while reading the back of the cereal packet. KATHY is eating cereal too, and has an open book in front of her... -.. but is tuned-in to RUTH and CHRISSIE’S conversation.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m not even saying I’1l apply to be a carer. Just several people have told me I’d be good at it. But then Laura went around telling people that I had been saying I was the most likely to get selected. CHRISSIE rolls her eyes.  70

dialogues.speaker: CHRISSIE
dialogues.text: That is so not true.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (echoes, in agreement) So not true. KATHY, subtly, reacts. p48. RUTH brings over a plate of scrambled eggs and puts them front of TOMMY. As she does so, she gives his shoulder a little squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 The kitchen is now empty apart from KATHY and RUTH, who stand at the sink, washing up. While KATHY washes, RUTH dries. For a while, they do this in silence. Then KATHY speaks.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Ruth, I’ve been meaning to ask you. Why do you do that thing - squeezing Tommy’s shoulder whenever you pass him? RUTH looks slightly confused.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m allowed to touch Tommy, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: It’s the way you’re touching him. You know what I’m talking about. The way you squeeze his shoulder. (beat) It’s copied from that television show.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That’s -

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (cuts in) And please don’t tell me ‘that’s so not true.’ RUTH shuts her mouth.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p49.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All that behaviour: it’s not what people do, out there, in real life, if that’s what you were thinking. Hold on RUTH’S face. She looks angry - but unsure how to fight back. So she shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: So what? It’s no big deal. A lot of us do it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What you mean is, Chrissie and Rod do it. And now the anger on RUTH’S face becomes, for a flashed moment, triumph. Which she quickly shifts into concern.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh, Kathy. So that’s what this is about. It must be awful for you, surrounded by all these couples.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (hotly) I never said that. I’m just saying it’s daft: you copy what they do, and they copy the TV show.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: But I’m right, aren’t I? And you don’t like the fact that Tommy and I are friends with Chrissie and Rod. Whereas you hardly talk to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: No, you're not right. RUTH raises her eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) ‘So’ not right? RUTH puts her drying cloth down, and walks out of the kitchen. Leaving KATHY alone.  71 72 73 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a field adjacent to the farm buildings, a car is drivi circles. Through the windscreen, we can see CHRISSIE behind the wheel. RODNEY is beside her. The car stalls as CHRISSIE grinds the gears viciously. Then it stops. CHRISSIE restarts the engine, puts the car in gear - - and almost immediately lurches, and stalls again. CHRISSIE bursts into tears. Although the intensity of her reaction might simply be he frustration at learning to drive, it feels somehow more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY is standing at the rear of the main farmhouse, holding a full rubbish-sack. She watches the motionless car in the field for a couple moments. It doesn’t restart. Then KATHY continues to the bins. When she opens the lid to put the rubbish-sack inside, sh sees, sitting on top of the bag already inside... «+. a Slightly crumpled PORNOGRAPHIC MAGAZINE. KATHY reacts. Then looks around, to see if anyone is near, or can see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daylight filters into what was once an old barn, and is n used as a general storage area. Judging by the dust and cobwebs, the space doesn’t get us much. KATHY enters, with the magazine.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p5l. She takes a seat... .»+. and starts to flick through the pictures. We watch KATHY scan the girls. She pauses on each image for the same amount of time, regardless of the pose of si of the photo. Her focus is their faces. KATHY is absorbed in what she is doing. And doesn’t notice at first that someone else has entered the barn, and is watching her. But she senses the presence. She tenses, and looks up. And sees TOMMY. TOMMY smiles, a little sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Hello, Kath.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Hi Tommy. (beat) Don’t just hover in the doorway. Come in. Join the fun. TOMMY walks over to where KATHY sits.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you liked that sort of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Girls are allowed to look too, aren’t we? Beat. KATHY starts flicking through the pages again.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t trying to spy on you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: You’re welcome to take them after I've finished. TOMMY gives a short laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I expect I’ve seen them all already.  74 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p52. A beat. KATHY looks up at TOMMY again - - and finds him returning her gaze with a serious expression.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kath - what are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What do you mean? I’m just looking at dirty pictures.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Just for kicks.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I suppose you could say that. TOMMY sits beside KATHY.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Kath, you don’t - (breaks off) If it’s for kicks, you don’t do it like that. You have to look at the pictures more carefully. Nothing really happens if you go that fast.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: How do you know what works for girls?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Kath. You aren’t looking for kicks. A beat. KATHY stands abruptly, and drops the magazine into TOMMY’ hands.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Here. Give it to Ruth. See if they do anything for her. She exits. TOMMY watches her go. INT. KATHY’S ROOM - DAY 74 KATHY is reading on her bed.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p53. RUTH enters.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Hi. RUTH sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I suppose you’ve heard what Chrissie and Rod have been saying. KATHY puts her book down, bristling slightly - thinking that this conversation will relate to their earlier exchange, and that in some way RUTH is going to rub KATHY nose in her friendship with the older couple.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: No. I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: They're probably just having me on. Their idea of a joke. Forget I mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: You obviously want to tell me. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You know that Rod and Chrissie have been thinking of applying to be carers. So they’ve been learning to drive.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Well - last weekend, Rod and Chrissie went for a drive together, and they went up to a town on the Norfolk coast. (beat) And they think they saw this person.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What person?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: A lady. Working in an open-plan office. And...  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p54. RUTH glances at KATHY, and suddenly KATHY sees how vulnerable and anxious RUTH looks. KATHY sits up, concerned, their earlier spat forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What is it, Ruth?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m sure it’s not true. Ora mistake. But - they thought this person was a ‘possible’. (beat) For me. KATHY looks genuinely amazed.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: They found your original?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: They aren’t sure, obviously. But Rodney said the resemblance was really striking. KATHY sits beside RUTH on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: My God, Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Rod and Chrissie want to drive me back up there, so I can see for myself. Tommy will come, but... I feel nervous...

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Do you want me to come too? This is clearly what RUTH was hoping for. KATHY takes RUTH’S hand.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ruth, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slightly battered estate car drives along an empty Norfolk A-road.  76 77 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RODNEY is driving, with CHRISSIE in the passenger seat. KATHY, TOMMY and RUTH are in the back.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: So - exactly how much experience have you guys had with the outside?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Quite a lot.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No we haven't!

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: We did a lot of role-playing exercises in Hailsham.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: They don’t count. RODNEY and CHRISSIE exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, don’t feel scared. There’s really nothing to it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: We aren’t scared.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: Good. CcuT TO -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY, RUTH, TOMMY, RODNEY and CHRISSIE all sit around a table in a small seaside cafe for lunch, looking at a men A WAITRESS is taking their order. As she waits for them to make up their minds, we see the WAITRESS reacts slightly to the sight of the bracelets. Not unlike MADAME, but perhaps better repressed. A frozen quality in her gaze that betrays the inward shudder.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: I‘1ll get sausage, egg, and chips.  78 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p56. The WAITRESS nods and turns to TOMMY - who looks slightly panicked, as if confronted with an elaborate menu at an intimidating French restaurant. So he defaults to RODNEY’ order.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Sausage, egg, and chips, please.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Yes. Sausage, egg, and chips.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Sausage, egg, and chips for me too. CHRISSIE laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISSIE
dialogues.text: I suppose I’d better get the same.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Right. Five sausage, egg and chips. Drinks? A beat. Then KATHY, RUTH and TOMMY all look to RODNEY.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: Five cokes, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The five of them eat their lunch. The cokes are circa 1970s bottles of cheap Corona Cola. TOMMY seems distracted by the sight of the sea and the shore line, just outside the window. They are eating in silence. Then CHRISSIE shoots a glance at RODNEY, who nods, almost imperceptibly. KATHY sees it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISSIE
dialogues.text: You know, there’s something I’ve been wanting to talk to you lot about. The problem is that back there, at the Cottages, it’s impossible. Someone is always listening in.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p57. Something about CHRISSIE’S tone feels a little over-casua Again, KATHY notices this - and also the way RODNEY has leaned forwards, and is now watching RUTH closely. CHRISSIE (CONT’D) So - it was just something we had heard about Hailsham students. Someone was saying that some Hailsham students, in the past, had managed to get a deferral. Apparently, those Hailsham students could have their first donation put back by three, or even four years. (beat) As long as they qualified. CHRISSIE pauses, and checks the faces of KATHY, TOMMY and RUTH, for any clue that they know what she is talking about.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: If there was a boy and a girl, and they were in love with each other - really, properly in love, and you could prove it - then you would be given a few years together, before you began your donations. TOMMY is frowning. Clearly, this story is news to him.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Where did you hear about this?

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: When we were at White Mansion.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISSIE
dialogues.text: People there used to go on about this Hailsham couple. And when the guy was only a few weeks from donation, he just went to see someone. He applied. And everything got sorted out.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: They got three years straight. Three years together, just to themselves. Because they could prove they were properly in love. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISSIE
dialogues.text: I suppose -  79 80 81

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH
dialogues.text: p58. CHRISSIE can no longer maintain the enforced casualness o her voice. CHRISSIE (CONT’D) - you lot would know about that. Being from Hailsham. You'd know the rules about that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: Who is it you go to? Who would you talk to if you wanted to apply? Silence. Until it is broken by TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: To be honest, I don’t know what you're talking about. A flash of anger in RODNEY’S face.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. Do you expect us to believe that? Everyone knows Hailsham is special. So what is it? Why keep all these things to yourself? Another silence. Then KATHY says, delicately:

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: There were lots of stories in Hailsham. I don’t think many of them turned out to be true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waves lap on a shingle beach.

dialogues.speaker: 82A
dialogues.text: SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. and RODNEY isn’t very sure where he’s going. He turns back to them, talking to no one in particular.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: I probably won’t be able to find this office again. In fact, I can’t even be sure this is the right town. RUTH is looking quietly desperate.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Please do try to remember, Rod.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: I’m doing my best. I’m just saying: none of this is looking very familiar. KATHY walks up to RODNEY and speaks quietly but firmly to him.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Rod - I hope you didn’t make up this possible for Ruth, just to create the opportunity to ask us about Hailsham.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t making it up.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Then I equally hope you are not failing to find the office as a punishment for us not knowing about this deferral scheme.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: .-. Of course I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Then find the office. Now. RODNEY nods, clearly a little taken aback by KATHY’S tone

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: It may have been down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY, TOMMY, RUTH, and CHRISSIE are walking down a stree in a seaside down, following RODNEY.  83 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p6o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On RODNEY’S FACE.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: ~-. Yes. He turns to the others.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s it. The five of them are looking towards an office building, over the road. The office is glass-fronted, and through the window we ca see a large, open-plan room, with a dozen desks arranged irregular L-patterns. Some of the OFFICE WORKERS are moving between the desks, chatting. Others have pulled their swivel chairs together and are drinking coffee or eating sandwiches. The sight of these workers - the sight of these normal lives, unfolding behind the glass - transfixes the five young adults.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: «+. Do you think it’s their lunch break?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It must be... With KATHY, RUTH, TOMMY, RODNEY and CHRISSIE, we watch th OFFICE WORKERS for a while. The way their mouths move. Smiling, talking. The way their eyebrows raise, or the way they shake they heads. The way they loosen their ties, or roll up their shirt sleeves. They way they drink their coffee. We are broken out of the moment by RUTH.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (quiet) Oh God. I think I see her. We see what RUTH sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pel. A WOMAN, about thirty years older than RUTH, in her late forties. And there is a resemblance there. Facially, and in the wa she has tied her hair... .+. but the resemblance is not striking.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s her. But it isn't. This woman is not RUTH’S genetic match, wit thirty years of age on her. And KATHY knows it. The five continue watching the WOMAN for several moments. ... then one of the other OFFICE WORKERS, a MAN, notices the five young adults across the road, all staring in at them. The MAN nudges the WOMAN beside him, and gives a slightly uncertain wave. This gesture breaks the spell over KATHY, RUTH, TOMMY, RODNEY and CHRISSIE... .».. and as one, they all turn and start to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RODNEY and CHRISSIE sit in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of a pier, in sight of the carpark, are KATHY, RUTH and TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It wasn’t her. (beat) Or - I’m not her.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: «+. No. You aren’t.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: But it was close, wasn’t it? I mean, you could see why Rod and Chrissie thought she might have been a possible.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh shut up, Tommy. It wasn’t close. It wasn’t close at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p62. An awkward beat. Then RUTH continues - cold anger growing in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I knew it wouldn’t be her before we even got there. It was never going to be her. They never, ever model us from people like that woman.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Ruth - don’t - But RUTH isn’t going to stop now.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: We all know it. We just never say it. We’re modelled from trash. Junkies, prostitutes, winos, tramps. Convicts, maybe, so long as they aren’t psychos. RUTH starts to walk back down the pier to the car. Then stops.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you want to look for possibles, if you want to do it properly, then look in the gutter. That’s where we come from. RUTH leaves TOMMY and KATHY alone. EXT. PIER - SUNSET 84a At the end of the pier, KATHY is gazing out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: We should go back. TOMMY doesn’t reply. He is watching KATHY. The light on her face. The way the wind pulls at her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is going down as they drive through Norfolk, back towards the Cottages.  86 87 88 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up at the cottages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hallway of the main house, just past the coat rack is a featureless metal box, attached to the wall, just li the one in Hailsham. The front door opens, and RUTH walks straight in. As she passes the metal box, she swipes it with her bracelet. TOMMY and KATHY follow behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY is cooking bacon over the stove. A couple of other faces from the Cottages are sat at the kitchen table, eating their dinner. Coming from the bedroom, we hear the sound of raised voices. An argument. Say:

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you’d say something like that. Do you actually want me to get angry?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then what do you want? If you don't want to make me angry, if you don’t want me to be upset, why would you say something so completely stupid? We can't fully make out the words, but we can recognise t voices as RUTH and TOMMY. It sounds as if RUTH is doing most of the shouting. People around the dining table look round at the noise, then exchange glances, then go back to whatever they were doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 90 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ped. KATHY slides the BACON out of the frying pan onto two slices of white bread, already buttered, then pushes the two slices together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY climbs the stairs, carrying her bacon sandwich up t her room. She can hear the argument more clearly here, because the living room door is open.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (angry) And a little back-up would be appreciated. A little support. How do you think it looks to everyone else?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calmer) It’s just not like that, Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So what is it like, Tommy? Spell it all out for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY sits in the front hall of the Cottages, pulling on pair of Wellington boots. She then stands, and opens the front door. It’s a beautiful morning outside. The sun is just coming up.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Where are you going? KATHY turns and sees TOMMY, through the open kitchen doorway. He’s at the dining table, on which is spread out a sheet paper. He is at the early stages of a large drawing.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I thought I’d go for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: ... Does that mean you want to be alone? Or can I come too?  91 92 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p65. INT. TOMMY’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS 91 RUTH stands at the window of TOMMY’S room, peering out of gap in the curtains... .+. watching TOMMY and KATHY walking away from the Cottages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and TOMMY walk through a large greenhouse attached the cottage complex. When TOMMY speaks, his words are deliberate. Pre-prepared This is a conversation he has internally rehearsed before now.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Chrissie and Rod are pretty obsessed with this rumour, aren’t they?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: About the deferrals. TOMMY nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I was thinking that if this rumour was true, it might explain quite a lot.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Well - the Gallery for instance. We never got to the bottom of it, what the Gallery was for. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pictures, poetry, sculptures. It tells you something about yourself. That’s the point about art, isn’t it? It says what’s inside you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: That’s what they used to tell us. It reveals your soul.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p66.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Exactly. Your soul. (beat) So suppose that the rumour is true. A special arrangement has been made for Hailsham students. If they’re in love. There would have to be a way to judge if couples are telling the truth, and not just lying to put off their donations. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well that’s what the Gallery would be for. In the Gallery, they can find out everything about us that they need to know. So if we say we’re in love, they can look into our souls, and they’1l know if it’s real love, or just a lie. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: That’s a strange idea, Tommy...

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Is it? I don’t see why it’s stranger than any other idea.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: .»+. and didn’t Miss Lucy tell you that making art for the Gallery wasn’t important?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Yes. She did. But look what happened to her. A moment between TOMMY and KATHY. Looking at each other. Then:

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Are you thinking of applying. You and Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It wouldn’t work. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Why?  94 95 96 97 On TOMMY. Beat. SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p67. Weighing up two possible answers.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: You forget. You had a lot accepted into the gallery. If I applied, they wouldn’t have anything to go on.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: You never got anything into the Gallery?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: It’s all just rumours and theories.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I know. But why else would the guardians have wanted us to work so hard on our art and poetry?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Tommy. I really don’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cottages, under a clear starry sky. INT. TOMMY’S ROOM - NIGHT RUTH and TOMMY are having sex. INT. KATHY’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS KATHY can hear RUTH and TOMMY. She reaches for the Walkman, and puts it on. For a few moments she is transported.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then: 94 95 96 97  98 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p6s. INT. KATHY’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS 98 The song ends. KATHY pulls off the headphones. Opens her eyes. Then JOLTS - - at the sight of a figure, standing in her doorway. It’s RUTH. She enters KATHY'S bedroom, and quietly closes the door behind her. Then she pads over to KATHY’S bed, and kneels down. The room is only lit by moonlight, filtering through the window. RUTH'S face, though close to KATHY’S, is in shadow. A strange beat. Then RUTH speaks.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (quiet) I know what you think, Kathy. (beat) I know you think that you and Tommy would have made a natural couple. And you believe there's a chance that Tommy and I will split up some day. And when we do, perhaps that will be your chance with Tommy. A chance to do it right this time. RUTH’S hand reaches out, and gently brushes against KATHY hair.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quiet) But the thing is, Kathy, although Tommy really likes you as a friend, he just doesn’t see you that way. RUTH laughs softly.  99 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p69.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quiet) Tommy told me all about the porno magazines. We had quite a laugh about it. RUTH voice lowers to barely whisper... .»+. and she puts her mouth so close to KATHY that she is almost kissing KATHY’S ear.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quiet) He didn’t understand what you were doing. But I did. A moment later, RUTH stands... «+. then leaves, closing the door softly behind her. A beat, on KATHY’S moonlit face. Her open eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEFFERS carries a box of groceries to the main house, whe KATHY is waiting at the front door. When KEFFERS hands her the box, KATHY doesn’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I want to be a carer. KEFFERS looks back at her blankly.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s you I apply to, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: KEFFERS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: So. I’m applying. KEFFERS nods.

dialogues.speaker: KEFFERS
dialogues.text: I‘1l bring you the forms tomorrow, and we can start to process. KATHY takes the box off KEFFERS.  100 101 102 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plastic bags. Litter in barbed wire.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By the time Ruth and Tommy finally separated, my carer training had already begun, so I was hardly ever at the Cottages. In the field by the cottages, we can see a figure standin TOMMY. He is looking away from the cottages - where we can see KEFFERS’ minibus is parked.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It had never occurred to me that our lives, until then so closely interwoven, could unravel and separate with such speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY is carrying a suitcase out of the front door to the Cottages... «+. towards the open boot of the minibus. Standing beside the minibus is KEFFERS.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If I had known, maybe I’d have kept tighter hold of them, and not let unseen tides pull us apart. A YOUNG MAN helps her with a second suitcase. From the doorway of the Cottage, two other young people, BOY and a GIRL, watch them. KATHY turns back and waves to the two standing in the doorway - - who wave back, smiling. KATHY'’S gaze flicks up to RUTH’S window -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p7l. - but no one is there. KATHY gets into the minibus... +. and KEFFERS drives her away.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: Title:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block of flats in early morning. INT. KATHY’S FLAT - CONTINUOUS 103 KATHY, aged twenty six, is lying on a single bed. Beside the bed, her alarm is sounding. KATHY switches it off. Swings her legs out the side of the bed. Rises to a sitting position. And rubs the sleep out of her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For the most part, being a carer has suited me fine. I can handle the solitude, the broken sleep, and the constant shuttle from clinic to clinic. We see around KATHY’S flat. It is Spartan, tidy, functional, and gives no indication a life shared with anyone else. There is a sense that KATHY only uses her flat for eating an early breakfast, or a late dinner, and sleeping. The one suggestion of a life outside work and sleep is, lined on a shelf, four desk lamps. Each a different colour.  104

dialogues.speaker: 104A
dialogues.text: 105 106 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p72. INT. KATHY’S FLAT - EARLY MORNING 104 KATHY leans against the counter of her kitchenette, eatin cereal, gazing absently out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The true test of a carer is when a donor completes earlier than expected, on the second or even first donation. Many go through the carer training, only to find they aren’t cut out for it. INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE KATHY’S FLAT - DAY 104A KATHY exits her flat, swipes her bracelet on the tracking system box, and locks the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY drives along an A-road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen through the doorway, KATHY sits beside a hospital be In the bed is a woman about KATHY’S age. HANNAH. HANNAH has one eye missing, and has bandages around her abdomen. KATHY pulls a packet of dark chocolate digestives from a plastic carrier bag.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Here you are. Dark chocolate. If you knew how many shops I had to try before I found them...

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I thought I wasn’t allowed to eat so soon before the operation. KATHY breaks the seal on the packet, and takes one biscui

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: You aren’t, but I am. And after the operation, you can wolf down the rest of the packet in one go.  107 108 109 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through glass, we see a MALE NURSE enter HANNAH'S ward * room.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd never say I’ve become immune to the completions. But they are something I am able to live with. Out of our earshot, KATHY and the NURSE talk for a few moments. Then KATHY stands, and kisses HANNAH on each cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dover Recovery Centre is in its own grounds. It is in countryside, but near enough to a motorway to he the soft rush of traffic, like wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY sits on a chair in a lounge area. * A few donor patients sit around watching TV, or playing * ping pong. All are damaged - with eyes, teeth, or limbs * missing. * She is asleep, dozing with her head resting to the side. Observed by one of the patients, a young FEMALE NURSE * approaches KATHY. *

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You’re Hannah's carer, aren’t you? KATHY stirs, and opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hannah's carer.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. Beat. KATHY scans the NURSE’S face, and understand immediately what she sees.  110 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p74.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. It’s always hard. But there were complications.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What kind of complications? The NURSE’S expression remains neutral.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Unexpected complications. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Right. KATHY stands. She looks very tired.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need me to sign the release.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Please. KATHY follows the NURSE to the ward desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY stands at the ward desk, filling out the forms that the NURSE puts in front of her. As KATHY writes:

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Are you going to leave now? We can quite easily provide you with a bed tonight if you've got a long drive. This is not a real offer.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I can be back home in under two hours.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Always better to wake at home, isn’t it? KATHY smiles perfunctorily at the NURSE’S polite small talk, and starts on the next form - - then seems to notice something.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p75. It’s on the COMPUTER SCREEN just behind the desk. KATHY swivels the screen in order to read it. On the screen is a medical information readout, and a sma passport-sized photo of RUTH.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it someone you know?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: ..-. Yes. Actually, we grew up together.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Oh. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: .«.. Were you close?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Very close as children. Though we haven’t seen each other now for nearly a decade.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Well, Ruth isn’t as strong as we would hope at this stage.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (checking the patient form) She’s done two donations. (looks up) You think she'll complete on the third. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I think she wants to complete. And as you know, when they want to complete, they usually do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY stands outside a ward room. She hesitates for a couple of moments. Then goes in.  112 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p76. INT. RUTH’S WARD ROOM - CONTINUOUS 112 KATHY enters RUTH’S ward room. The bed is empty. The room feels very still. KATHY walks up to the bed. On the bedside table is a glas of water, half-full, and an open copy of a novel, the spi bent back to keep its place. KATHY checks over her shoulder, then opens the bedside table drawer. She sees a wrist-watch, and some hair-clips... -».- and a single Hailsham token. Kept like a lucky casin chip. KATHY reacts. Then shuts the drawer. Almost as soon as she has done so, KATHY hears a noise. The toilet in the bathroom flushes. KATHY turns, and, a moment later, the door to the toilet opens. Revealing RUTH. She is struggling slightly to exit the bathroom, because she is having to use a walker in order to stay upright, a it’s awkward manoeuvring it past the self-closing door. So for a moment or two, she doesn’t notice KATHY. Then she has the walker past the doorframe. And looks up. Then freezes at the sight of KATHY. Momentarily stunned, dislocated. For a moment, the two women gaze at each other. Then the moment is broken - - as a smile breaks over RUTH’S face.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Kathy.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and RUTH walk down a corridor in the Dover Recovery Centre. RUTH'S progress, using her walker, is slow.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’ve kept tabs on you over the years. (beat) And Tommy too.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What do you hear about Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: That he’s done his second donation too. And apparently, he’s doing very well on it. Apparently, he’s in better shape than some after their first donation.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Good old Tommy. I’m not surprised.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: «+. Are you surprised at me? (beat) I expect I look a bit broken, Kath. KATHY makes no response.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But that’s okay. I’m not sure I'd want to survive the third donation anyway. You hear things, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: +. What kind of things?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh, you know. How maybe, after the fourth donation, even if you've technically completed, you're still conscious in some sort of way. And then you find out there are more donations. Plenty of them. Except there are no more recovery centres, and no more carers. There’s just watching, and waiting. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p78.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until they switch you off. (beat) I don’t think I fancy that. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it the end of the day already? KATHY looks up to the sky. The sun is low.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s funny. Over the last few months, I’ve probably thought about you every day. Hoping I'd see you. And actually I felt sure I would. It seemed impossible that I’d complete without seeing you one last time. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: It’s not the last time, yet, Ruth. They offered me a bed here. I was planning to stay the night anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the windows in the recovery center remain lit throug the night. 115 INT. RUTH’S WARD ROOM - DAY 115 The following morning. KATHY is peeling an orange, watched by RUTH - who is lyin in her bed, propped up on pillows. KATHY pulls the segments neatly apart, then hands them to RUTH. RUTH smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I knew you’d be a good carer. Your donors are very lucky. KATHY smiles back.  A moment.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look - I was lying awake last night, and I suddenly had an idea that we’d take a trip together.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (casual) I didn’t much think of where. Just a trip.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though a place did occur to me. One of the boys on the next floor was telling me about it. It’s near the Kingsfield recovery center. KATHY reacts slightly to the name Kingsfield. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Is it the boat? The one stranded on the beach?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You're heard about it too?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: From a carer who had worked there. (beat) It’s quite a drive from here. Are you sure you’re up to it?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Quite sure.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (gently) And do you suppose, if we're driving all that way, we could think about calling in on Tommy? Seeing as he’s staying at Kingsfield. Another beat - then RUTH smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told you I’d been keeping tabs on both of you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: p79.  116 117 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ps0.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Have you seen him?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Not since the Cottages. RUTH nods.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No. Neither have I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large, automated cast iron gates. A sign reads: Kingsfield Recovery Centre The gates start to swing open, and KATHY’S car drives through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY drives up towards the main building. Outside the front doors, there is a group of four people, patients, standing and chatting. RUTH makes a sudden sharp intake of breath.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Look. There he is. One of the figures is TOMMY. Older, hair cut short, thinner. But entirely recognisable. He turns to watch the approaching car.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think he’s recognised us through the glass? As if in answer, TOMMY lifts his hand, as if shielding hi eyes from overhead light, and squints at them. This sends RUTH into a slight panic.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do we do? Do we get out? No, no, let’s not get out. But KATHY has already opened the door. We stay in the car with RUTH -  118 119 120 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH psi. - who watches, like a silent film, as TOMMY walks towards KATHY. Then hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we are with TOMMY and KATHY... ++. aS KATHY is spun round by TOMMY’S embrace - - so that she now faces RUTH, watching through the car windscreen. RUTH face is oddly blank, almost frozen, as if she is watching people in a play.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (pulling back) Ruth’s in the car. TOMMY pulls back from KATHY, and goes to open the passeng door... .»+. and now it is KATHY’S turns to watch through the windscreen, as TOMMY leans in and kisses RUTH on each cheek. It is a different kind of greeting. More restrained. And KATHY can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY’S car drives down a narrow, winding country road. Almost a dirt-track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY drives, with RUTH still in the passenger seat, and TOMMY in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I can't believe I have the two of you here. Does it feel to you like we’re back at Hailsham again? Like no time has passed?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: No. It doesn’t. TOMMY laughs.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ps2.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No, it doesn’t at all, does it! It feels really weird. (beat) But good weird! TOMMY laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I suppose you both heard that Hailsham was closed. From what you hear, the only schools left now are like Morningdale. Like battery farms, they say. (beat) I’m sure it’s an exaggeration. RUTH is looking out of the passenger window a little anxiously, as the narrow road gets rougher and more overgrown.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is the right way?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY stops the car. The dirt track has come to an end. KATHY and TOMMY exit the car. RUTH opens her door and peers out. Again, we see the same slight panic in RUTH that we saw when they arrived at Kingsfield and saw TOMMY. It is as if, over the intervening years, all her power and authori has gone.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: My walker is going to be useless here.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. We’ll carry you. RUTH sees that the way ahead is blocked by a tangled barb wire fence.  122 123

dialogues.speaker: 123A
dialogues.text: SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ps3.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh no. No one said anything about this. No one said anything about barbed wire.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Ruth, just relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and TOMMY carry RUTH, with one of her arms around each of their shoulders. RUTH is not paralysed - she just has very little power in her legs. But the effort for TOMMY and KATHY is considerable.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Kath - really, are you absolutely sure - KATHY snaps slightly.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Oh do be quiet, Ruth. I’ve already told you I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Yes, Ruth. For God’s sake. RUTH closes her mouth, and sinks a little deeper into herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them exit the forest... ... into sand dunes. And there, a little way ahead of them, is a BOAT. An old fishing vessel - sat in the dunes as if ina snapshot. Listing slightly. Paint peeling, rusting, and rotting.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (quiet) Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOMMY has climbed on to the boat. Right up to the cabin. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ps4. Looks back at RUTH and KATHY, and waves. KATHY and RUTH are on the banks of the dune that overlook the boat. KATHY is standing. RUTH is seated. KATHY waves back to TOMMY, but RUTH doesn’t appear to see Apparently lost in her own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOMMY and KATHY sit beside RUTH on the dune, facing the boat.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Maybe this is what Hailsham looks like now. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you ever hear, Kath. About the other students from Hailsham?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I heard that Amanda completed on her first donation.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I think that happens more than they ever tell us.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: There’s no conspiracy. It does happen sometimes. But it’s not common. TOMMY keeps gazing at the boat.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: There was a guy, at my centre. He always worried he wouldn't make it past his first donation. But it all turned out fine. He’s come through his third now, and he’s completely all right. (beat) It’s funny. I don’t think I'd have been a good carer. But ina way I think I’m a pretty good donor.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pss.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Well, it’s what we’re supposed to be doing, isn’t it? Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like you both to forgive me. I don’t expect you to. A long silence. None of them look at each other. Then:

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: «+. Forgive you for what?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Keeping you and Tommy apart. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It should have been you two together. I always knew it, as far back as I can remember. But I kept you apart. It wasn’t just because of the rumours about deferrals. It was because I was jealous. You had real love, and I didn’t. And - RUTH takes a breath. This is the truth, and it’s hard.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to be the one that was left alone. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the worst thing I ever did. (beat) And now I want to put it right.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (quiet) I don’t know how you can do that, Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Iocan. If the two of you get a deferral.  124 125 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ps6. Tears start running down KATHY’S face, and she wipes them away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: It’s too late for that. Way too late. It’s stupid to even think about it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It’s not too late. Tommy. You tell her. TOMMY says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll see. Both of you. I wanted to do this trip because I had something to give you. RUTH reaches into her pocket and pulls out a crumpled pie of paper. She hands it to TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Madame’s address. That’s who you apply to. That’s who you have to go and see.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: -+. How did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It wasn’t easy. But I’ve had years to think about what I did, and years to work out how to make it better. (beat) Now it’s up to you two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breeze whips up sand around the fishing boat. The tide is coming in, lapping around the wood. KATHY, TOMMY and RUTH have gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - of a drawing.  126 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ps7. Many thousands of careful pen-strokes build up to depict ELEPHANT standing in tall grass. It is oddly similar to the clumsy drawing that TOMMY did a child. In fact, compositionally it is the same. But this drawing shows the opposite of clumsiness. If anything, it shows a meticulous care, bordering on obsessive. And there is something strange about the surface of the elephant. It is drawn as if it is reflective, or metallic

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you think? INT. KINGSFIELD/TOMMY’S WARD ROOM - NIGHT 126

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY sits on the floor of TOMMY’S room in Kingsfield. She is surrounded by more of these intricate black and white pictures, all depicting different animals. But the one she holds is of the elephant.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I started doing them when we were in the Cottages. After that trip to find Ruth’s possible. I realised, you see. If I was ever going to apply for a deferral, I'd need something to show them. (beat) I’ve done hundreds over the years.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: They’re wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Really? I never showed anyone until now. They were my secret. (beat) Like you reading those porno magazines. KATHY looks up.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: You remember that?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: «+. Ruth said you didn’t understand what I was doing.  127 128 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pss.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No. I think she didn’t understand what you were doing. She thought you were looking at the dirty pictures in order to find out about sex. To find out what you were missing. (beat) But I knew you were looking for your original. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I used to get these huge urges to have sex. Sometimes they were so powerful I thought I’d do it with anyone. (beat) So I thought that had to tell me something. Something about what kind of person I was modelled from. I guessed the magazines would be the most likely place I'd find her.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: You know those urges are natural, don’t you? Normal. We all had them. You know that now.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. I know that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights glow in Kingsfield. Through one of the windows, we can see TOMMY lying in his bed, and KATHY in the chair beside him, reading to him fr a book. INT. KINGSFIELD/TOMMY’S WARD ROOM - CONTINUOUS 128

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY is reading from One Thousand And One Nights.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I embarked on a ship to the city of El-Basrah, with a company of merchants, and we traversed the sea for many days and nights. Passing island after island, sea to sea, land to land. In each place, we bought and sold, and exchanged merchandise.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH
dialogues.text: KATHY glances at TOMMY as she reads.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until we arrived at one island like the gardens of paradise, and the master of the ship cast anchor there. KATHY looks round at TOMMY’S face again.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (quiet) Don’t stop. KATHY watches him for a few moments. Then she puts the book down. Stands. And gets into bed. With her eyes never leaving his face, the sheets towards TOMMY. Then she leans forwards and starts to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun sinking over the recovery center. her hand slips kiss him. EXT. DOVER RECOVERY CENTRE/RUTH’S WARD ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH sits by her window. ps9. under

dialogues.speaker: 128A
dialogues.text: 129 She looks even weaker, skin even greyer, than the last ti we saw her. KATHY sits by her.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: We're going to do it. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you should know.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You're going to apply.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. RUTH closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 130 131 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pg90d.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY is walking down a quiet street. A MAN is walking just ahead of her, carrying a bunch of multicoloured balloons. KATHY is fixated on the fist holding the strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY is seated on a seafront bench. She watches elderly people making their way down the promenade. She holds the address RUTH gave her. Her gaze is directed at one house in particular. As she watches, in the background, a tall Nigerian man - GEORGE - pushes an old woman on a wheelchair. The old woman is wrapped and sunk into a blanket, and though we do not see her face, it is in fact MISS EMILY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and TOMMY walk around the Kingsfield grounds, by a swimming pool which has been filled-in with concrete.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I checked the address. (beat) We just go there. Next week, I’ll take you for lab tests. I‘1l sign you out for the whole day. And we'll visit Madame on the way back. TOMMY nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: If we get this - she gives us the deferral - and she gives us, say, three years, just to ourselves... what do we do? Where will we go?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe they’1ll send us back to the Cottages. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 132 133 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pol.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or maybe they have a separate place for people like us. We’1l have to wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: We'll have to decide which of my pictures to take. We’1ll only take the best. Maybe six or seven or them.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. As they walk, KATHY takes TOMMY’S hand.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (repeats) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUTH is strapped to an operating table. She is surrounded by SURGEONS and NURSES, who are operati on her opened torso. Her eyes are open, but glazed. RUTH blinks once. The alarm on the heart-rate monitor starts to sound. No one takes any notice. RUTH flatlines. The operation continues, unaffected. Concludes. And the various operating staff finish up. Scrub down. Exit. Leaving RUTH, her cadaver, on the operating table. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and TOMMY sit in the car - - looking at a red brick terraced house. A woman is outside the house, weeding large terra-cotta planters in the front garden. The woman is MADAME.  134 135 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pg2. EXT. MADAME’S HOUSE - DAY 134 KATHY and TOMMY approach the front gate. MADAME doesn’t appear to notice them.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Madame. MADAME starts - and looks up. Confused.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn’t mean to startle you. But we were at Hailsham. I’m Kathy. This is Tommy. (beat) We haven't come to give you any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: From Hailsham... (beat) If you haven’t come to give me trouble, then why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: We came to talk to you. I’ve brought you some things. TOMMY lifts his bag.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some things you might want for your Gallery. A long beat, as MADAME gazes at them, head tilted slightl Then she nods.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: Very well, then. Come inside. INT. MADAME’S HOUSE/LIVING ROOM - DAY 135

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inside of the house is dark, and MADAME doesn’t switc on the lights. MADAME ushers TOMMY and KATHY into the living room, then dissapears. The living room was once two rooms, with the partition wa removed, now replaced by a sliding screen. The interior is lit by what light filters through the net curtains.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p93. It reveals a Victorian living room, with period furniture and a feeling of dust and age. On one wall are two agit-prop posters, in support of the Hailsham movement. Opposite, a large watercolour of Hailsham is hung above t fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Look. He indicates the watercolour to KATHY. They talk quietly.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Hailsham. It’s the bit around the back of the pond.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: What do you mean? There’s no pond here.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No, the pond’s behind you. KATHY seems slightly taken aback by the irritation in TOMMY'’S voice.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must be able to remember. If you’re round the back, with the pond behind you...

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. Their quiet exchange is silenced by noise on the far side of the sliding screen: MADAME moving about. Then the sliding screen is pulled back... ... but apparently for no purpose. The rear half of the living room - beyond what was once the partition wall - i almost completely in shadow. With the screen fully pulled back, MADAME enters the lit area of the room, and indicates that they should sit. MADAME takes a seat in an armchair beside the fireplace, and KATHY and TOMMY sit on the sofa opposite. As they get comfortable, there is a soft mechanical whirring sound from the dark half of the living room, whi KATHY is distracted by. Then brought back to focus by MADAME.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pod.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: So. Long beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: We’re in love. TOMMY turns to KATHY. Then back to MADAME.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're in love. True love. Verifiable.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: We would never have bothered you if we weren’t really sure.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: Verifiable. I see. (beat) Go on.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Well, we’d heard about the deferrals. And we'd worked out the purpose of the Gallery.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: Tell me the purpose.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: To use our art from Hailsham to look into our souls, which would verify that we deserved a deferral. MADAME does not react.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The trouble is, I was a bit mixed up in those days. I didn’t really do any art, so you never took anything. I know that’s my fault, and it’s probably much too late... He reaches down and opens his bag.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +. but I brought some things with me now. He starts to lay the drawings out on the floor for MADAME to see.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH pos.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some were done quite recently, but a lot of them are several years old, so there’s a spread. And you should have Kath’s stuff already. She got plenty into the Gallery, didn’t you, Kath?

dialogues.speaker: ON KATHY -
dialogues.text: - looking at MADAME. She's a step ahead of TOMMY. Realising the mistake that she and TOMMY have made. Perhaps because, deep down, she already knew.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. (beat) I don’t know what to do at this point. I never know what to do. Should I let them continue, or should I stop them now? Silence. It takes a moment to realise that this question was not asked to the ether, but was directed at someone in particular. Someone actually in the room, who has not yet been revealed.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s you they’ve really come to see.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I suppose it is. The VOICE has come from the darkness at the rear of the living room. And from that darkness now comes the metallic whirring again. A wheel turning.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll take it from here. A moment later, out of the darkness, MISS EMILY appears.  SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH py6. A shrunken figure, pushed forwards on a wheelchair by her nurse, GEORGE.

dialogues.speaker: MISS EMILY
dialogues.text: Leave us, George. I’11 call when I’m done. GEORGE turns and goes. A moment between MISS EMILY, KATHY and TOMMY. KATHY and TOMMY are frozen with surprise. MISS EMILY (CONT’D) Kathy H and Tommy D. I remember you both. Kathy, a bright girl, and so creative. Tommy, a big heart. And terrible rages. TOMMY remains motionless, holding one his drawings in his hand. MISS EMILY (CONT’D) We used to get two or three couples like you a year. But not so much these days. (beat) You're the first for quite a while. TOMMY still doesn’t quite understand.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: To apply for a deferral.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: (quiet) There are no deferrals, Tommy. TOMMY looks at KATHY, uncomprehending. Then back at MADAME. Who gently confirms.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: There are no deferrals. And there never have been. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MISS EMILY
dialogues.text: We didn’t have the Gallery in order to look into your souls. We had the Gallery in order to see if you had souls at all. In the silence, MADAME stands.  136 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH po7. She goes to the Hailsham watercolour above the fireplace, and gazes at it a moment. MISS EMILY (CONT’D) Hailsham was the last place to consider the ethics of donation. We used your art to show what you were capable of. To show that donor children were all but human. But it was all a mistake. We were providing an answer to a question that no one was asking. MISS EMILY glances at MADAME. Then back to TOMMY and KATHY. MISS EMILY (CONT’D) You have to understand. Cancer used to kill almost everyone. Now it kills no one at all. (beat) You see, it’s not an ethical issue. It’s just about the way we are. If you ask people to return to darkness, the days of lung cancer, and breast cancer, and motor neurone disease... (she shrugs) «+. they simply say no. Beat. MISS EMILY (CONT’D) Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Yes. MADAME turns to TOMMY.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: Your drawings are very good. If you want, I’ll keep them. TOMMY doesn’t answer. He just stares blankly into space. EXT. MADAME’S HOUSE - DAY 136 TOMMY and KATHY leave MADAME’S house. TOMMY walks ahead of KATHY, straight to the car parked outside, and gets inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p98. KATHY pauses at the doorway, where MADAME stands.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Thank you for talking to us. MADAME says nothing. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know what you’re thinking. MADAME reacts, slightly dreamily, as if she has momentari lost focus.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: There was a time you saw me. It was one afternoon, in the dormitories. There was no one else around, and I was playing this tape. This music. MADAME smiles distantly.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) I still think about that occasion from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: ++. So do I. A beat. Then MADAME reaches out, and touches KATHY’S cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME
dialogues.text: You poor creatures. I wish I could help you. But you’re by yourselves now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY and TOMMY drive in silence through countryside, bac towards Kingsfield. Shadows are long. The countryside is bathed in the last o the day’s sunlight. Fields line the road on either side.  138 139 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH p99.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Could you stop the car? I’m sorry. I need to get out a minute. KATHY turns to TOMMY, but TOMMY is looking directly ahead his gaze fixed on an indeterminate point. KATHY slows the car, pulls over to the side of the road. They stop on a small grass verge. Without saying another word, TOMMY gets out of the car, a shuts the door behind him. Leaving KATHY in a little bubble of silence. She watches as TOMMY walks a short way down the road. Then stops, caught in the glare of the headlights. Then, just as he did as young boy, on the playing field - - he throws his head back and starts to scream at the sky Insulated from the sound, KATHY watches. Then she opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY walks to TOMMY. KATHY and TOMMY stand by KATHY’S car. They embrace, holding each other tightly for several moments. Eventually, FADE TO -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY, twelve, sits in the art room. She sees TOMMY, studiously working on his drawing. Sees RUTH, working on her own drawing. She watches them for several moments. In the afternoon sunshine. The tree tops moving in the wind outside the ar room windows. Then TOMMY looks up at KATHY and smiles.  140 141 142 SHOOTING SCRIPT 24TH MARCH ploo.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tommy completed on his fourth donation. cur TO -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY’S car is driving along an empty road.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve been given my notice now. My first donation is in six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY isn’t sobbing, but her eyes are filling with tears.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What I’m not sure about is whether our lives have been so different from the lives of the people we save. We all complete. She pulls over to the side of the road, and gets out of t car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY stands by the roadside, collecting herself. By the road are fences, lining the fields. And caught in the barbed wire... ++. are hundreds of abandoned plastic bags.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And none of us really understand what we've lived through. Or feel we've had enough time.
